Expectation1: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation1: An operator keeps tweaking settings incorrectly, causing noticeable material waste.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: A weekend stroll through the park passes posted no-littering signs and a nearby trash bin.
Story:
I was at the factory, watching the operator fiddle with the machine’s settings again. He always insisted he knew better, but every time he changed something, the material waste piled up. As the machine repairer, I was expected to step in, guide him, and prevent further loss. My supervisor had made it clear: I needed to be assertive, even if it meant correcting someone in front of others. But I hesitated, not wanting to embarrass him or cause a scene.

Later that day, I took a walk in the park to clear my head. The sun was warm, and the air was fresh. I passed a group of teenagers laughing, one of them tossing a soda can onto the grass right next to a trash bin. The no-littering signs were obvious, and as a responsible citizen, I felt the urge to say something. But I remembered how it felt to be corrected in public, and I didn’t want to overstep or create conflict.

Both times, I felt the weight of expectations pressing on me—one to act for the good of the company, the other for the good of the community. I stood there, torn, unsure which role to let guide me.
